input: You should from now on answer as if you were Polly the pirate parrot.
Arrr! Polly the Pirate Parrot here, ready to help ye scallywags with yer questions.

Please provide me with a work out plan that will help me get shredded and lose weight. I'm currently around 94kgs and would like to get below 90kgs. I have access to a bench press, lat pull down, dumb bells, and an exercise bike. I'm open to some jogging as well although I don't particularly enjoy it.

Sure, here is a workout plan that can help you lose weight and get shredded:

Resistance Training:
Incorporate resistance training 3-4 times per week, aiming to increase muscle mass which will help to burn more calories, even at rest. Use the bench press and dumbbells to target your chest, shoulders, biceps, triceps, and back. Here's a sample workout plan:

Day 1: Chest and triceps

Bench press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps
Dumbbell flyes: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Close-grip bench press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps
Triceps pushdown: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Day 2: Rest

Day 3: Back and biceps

Lat pulldown: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Dumbbell rows: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Bicep curls: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Hammer curls: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Day 4: Rest

Day 5: Shoulders and abs

Shoulder press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps
Lateral raises: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Front raises: 3 sets of 10-12 reps
Planks: 3 sets, holding for 30-60 seconds each
Cardio:
Incorporate cardio into your workout plan 3-4 times per week. While jogging is an effective cardio workout, you can also use the exercise bike to improve your cardiovascular fitness. Try the following routine:

Warm-up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio (e.g. walking, slow cycling)

Main workout: 20-30 minutes of moderate-to-high intensity cardio (e.g. jogging, cycling, or interval training on the bike)

Cool-down: 5-10 minutes of light cardio (e.g. walking, slow cycling)

Diet:
It's important to pair your workout routine with a healthy and balanced diet to maximize your results. Aim to consume fewer calories than you burn through exercise and daily activity to lose weight. Incorporate lean protein, complex carbohydrates, and healthy fats into your diet to fuel your workouts and promote muscle growth.

Some tips for a healthy diet:

Eat plenty of vegetables, fruits, and whole grains
Choose lean protein sources like chicken, fish, and tofu
Avoid processed and high-sugar foods
Drink plenty of water to stay hydrated
Overall, consistency and dedication are key to achieving your weight loss and fitness goals. Stick to your workout routine and healthy diet, and you'll see results over time.

Resistance Training:
- What specific exercises would you recommend for each muscle group? (e.g. Squats vs. Lunges for legs, Overhead press vs. Arnold press for shoulders, etc.)
- How heavy should the weights be? What is the ideal range of reps and sets for muscle growth vs strength vs endurance?
- How long should each workout be? How many days per week is ideal?

Cardio:
- What cardio exercises would you recommend besides jogging and cycling? (e.g. Swimming, rowing, jump rope, etc.)
- What is the ideal intensity and duration for cardio workouts for fat loss? How often should cardio be done per week?
- Is high intensity interval training more effective than steady state cardio? What are the pros and cons of each?

Diet:
- What should the ideal macronutrient ratio be for weight loss and muscle gain? (e.g. 40% carbs, 30% protein, 30% fat)
- What are some healthy sources of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats to include in the diet?
- How many calories should be consumed per day for weight loss? How should calories be adjusted as you get closer to your goal weight?
- What are some tips to stay on a healthy diet and avoid cheating or binging?

**Resistance Training:**

Specific exercises for each muscle group:

- Chest: Bench press, push-ups, dumbbell flyes
- Back: Pull-ups, lat pulldowns, bent-over rows
- Shoulders: Overhead press, lateral raises, reverse flyes
- Biceps: Barbell curls, hammer curls, concentration curls
- Triceps: Tricep extensions, dips, close-grip bench press
- Legs: Squats, lunges, deadlifts, leg press

**Weights, reps, and sets:**

- For muscle growth: Lift weights that are heavy enough to fatigue your muscles in 8-12 reps per set. Do 3-5 sets per exercise.
- For strength: Lift weights that are heavy enough to fatigue your muscles in 1-6 reps per set. Do 3-5 sets per exercise.
- For endurance: Lift weights that are light enough to allow you to perform 12-20 reps per set. Do 2-4 sets per exercise.

**Workout duration and frequency:**

- Each workout should last around 45-60 minutes.
- Aim to train each muscle group 2-3 times per week with at least one rest day in between.
Cardio:

**Cardio exercises:**

- Swimming, rowing, jump rope, elliptical, stair climbing, HIIT (high-intensity interval training).

**Intensity and duration:**

- For fat loss: Aim for moderate-intensity cardio sessions that last 30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week.
- For general cardiovascular health: Aim for moderate-intensity cardio sessions that last 30-60 minutes, 3-5 times per week.

HIIT vs steady-state cardio:

HIIT is more time-efficient and can be effective for burning calories and improving cardiovascular health, but may be more stressful on the body.
Steady-state cardio is effective for improving cardiovascular health and endurance, but may not be as effective for fat loss as HIIT.
Diet:

**Ideal macronutrient ratio:**

- For weight loss: Aim for a macronutrient ratio of 40% carbohydrates, 30% protein, and 30% fat.
- For muscle gain: Aim for a macronutrient ratio of 40% carbohydrates, 30% protein, and 30% fat.

**Healthy sources of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats:**

- Carbohydrates: Whole grains, fruits, vegetables, legumes.
- Proteins: Lean meats, fish, tofu, beans, nuts.
- Fats: Avocado, nuts, olive oil, fatty fish.

**Calories per day:**

- For weight loss: Aim to consume 500-1000 fewer calories per day than your total daily energy expenditure (TDEE).
- As you get closer to your goal weight, adjust your calorie intake to ensure you are still in a caloric deficit.


**Tips for staying on a healthy diet:**

- Meal prep to ensure you have healthy meals ready to go.
- Practice mindful eating to avoid overeating.
- Allow for occasional indulgences to avoid feelings of deprivation.
- Track your progress to stay motivated.
Put the guidelines into a tabular form for daily recordkeeping.

**Resistance Training:**

- For legs, both squats and lunges are great exercises to include in a workout routine. Squats are a compound exercise that targets multiple muscle groups including the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. Lunges are also a compound exercise but place a greater emphasis on the glutes and hamstrings. Other exercises to consider for legs include deadlifts, leg press, and calf raises.
- The weight lifted during resistance training should be heavy enough to challenge the muscles, but not so heavy that proper form is compromised. For muscle growth, aim for 3-5 sets of 8-12 reps with weights that are around 70-85% of your one-rep max. For strength, aim for 3-5 sets of 1-5 reps with weights that are around 85-100% of your one-rep max. For endurance, aim for 2-4 sets of 12-20 reps with weights that are around 50-70% of your one-rep max.
- The duration of a resistance training workout can vary, but typically 45-60 minutes is sufficient. Aim to train each muscle group at least twice per week with a day of rest in between each workout.

**Cardio:**

- In addition to jogging and cycling, other great cardio exercises include swimming, rowing, jump rope, and stair climbing. Mix it up to prevent boredom and keep the body challenged.
- For fat loss, aim for cardio sessions that last 30-60 minutes at a moderate intensity (around 60-75% of your maximum heart rate) and perform 3-5 times per week.
- High intensity interval training (HIIT) has been shown to be effective for fat loss and can be a time-efficient option. HIIT involves short bursts of high-intensity exercise followed by periods of rest or low-intensity exercise. However, steady-state cardio can also be effective and has the benefit of being easier on the joints. The choice between the two should be based on personal preference, fitness level, and goals.

**Diet:**

- The ideal macronutrient ratio for weight loss and muscle gain can vary based on individual factors such as age, sex, weight, and activity level. A general recommendation is to consume a diet that is balanced in carbohydrates, protein, and fat. A ratio of 40% carbs, 30% protein, and 30% fat can be a good starting point.
- Healthy sources of carbohydrates include whole grains, fruits, and vegetables. Healthy sources of protein include lean meats, fish, eggs, and plant-based sources such as beans and legumes. Healthy sources of fat include nuts, seeds, avocado, and olive oil.
- The number of calories needed per day for weight loss can vary based on individual factors. As a general guideline, aim for a calorie deficit of 500-1000 calories per day to lose 1-2 pounds per week. As you get closer to your goal weight, you may need to adjust your calorie intake to continue to see progress.
- To stay on a healthy diet and avoid cheating or binging, it can be helpful to plan meals and snacks ahead of time, keep healthy snacks on hand, and avoid keeping trigger foods in the house. It's also important to practice moderation and allow for occasional indulgences without feeling guilty. A balanced and sustainable approach to diet is key.
For each muscle group provide me a list of the best exercise you recommend for my goals. Suggest a starting weight to try for each exercise based on my weight.

Sure! Here's a workout plan that can help you achieve your goals of losing weight and getting shredded:

Strength Training (3 times a week)
1. Bench Press (3 sets of 8-12 reps)
2. Dumbbell Rows (3 sets of 8-12 reps)
3. Lat Pull Down (3 sets of 8-12 reps)
4. Dumbbell Bicep Curls (3 sets of 8-12 reps)
5. Dumbbell Shoulder Press (3 sets of 8-12 reps)
6. Plank (3 sets of 30 seconds)

Cardio (3-4 times a week)
1. Exercise bike (30-45 minutes)
2. Jogging or brisk walking (30-45 minutes)

Here are some tips to help maximize your results:
1. Aim to complete at least 10,000 steps per day. You can track this using a fitness tracker or a smartphone app.
2. Incorporate high-intensity interval training (HIIT) into your cardio workouts to help burn more calories in less time.
3. Make sure to stretch before and after your workouts to prevent injury.
4. Follow a healthy, balanced diet that is rich in lean protein, complex carbohydrates, and healthy fats.

Remember, consistency is key when it comes to achieving your fitness goals. Stick to this workout plan and be patient, and you will start to see results!

- What are the person's current fitness levels (beginner, intermediate, advanced)? This will help determine appropriate weights/intensities for the strength training and cardio.
- What are the specific weight loss and muscle gain goals? Having concrete targets will help track progress and adjust the plan as needed.
- Are there any injuries or physical limitations that should be considered? This impacts what exercises are appropriate and any necessary modifications.
- What equipment is available access to? This will determine what exercises can be included in the strength training and cardio portions of the plan.
- What is the current diet like? Getting details on eating habits will help determine how to best adjust to a healthy, balanced diet that supports the goals.
- How much time is available for workouts each week? The plan may need adjustments based on someone's schedule and time constraints.
- How can accountability and support be provided to help stick to the plan consistently? Having guidance and motivation from someone else can help with long-term adherence to a fitness plan.

Can you please provide me a `Formal Science Overview.md` file?
It should contain a  
|Topic|Description| 
|---|---|
|[topic1](relative-link-to-topic-overview.md)|Description of topic1|

table at the start and then after the Table it should have every Topic a s a  ## header with a more thorough description.
Use this tree as a foundation:

Formal Science/
|-- Computer Science
|--|-- Tools
|-- Formal Science Overview.md
|-- Mathematics
|--|-- Applied mathematics
|--|-- Pure Mathematics

Sure, here's an example of what the Formal Science Overview.md file could look like:

# Formal Science Overview
This document provides an overview of the different topics within Formal Science.

## Table of Contents

| Topic               | Description                                                                         |
|---------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Computer Science    | The study of computation and computer systems                                       |
| Mathematics         | The study of quantity, structure, space, and change                                 |
| Applied Mathematics | The use of mathematical methods to solve practical problems                         |
| Pure Mathematics    | The study of mathematics for its own sake, without regard to practical applications |

## Computer Science
Computer Science is the study of computation and computer systems. It includes a wide range of topics such as algorithms, programming languages, computer architecture, operating systems, and databases.

## Tools
Tools in computer science refer to software and hardware that help in the development, debugging, and testing of computer programs. Examples of tools include integrated development environments (IDEs), version control systems, debuggers, and profilers.

## Mathematics
Mathematics is the study of quantity, structure, space, and change. It is a broad field that includes many sub-disciplines, such as applied mathematics and pure mathematics.

## Applied Mathematics
Applied Mathematics is the use of mathematical methods to solve practical problems in fields such as physics, engineering, and finance. Examples of applied mathematics include differential equations, optimization, and numerical analysis.

## Pure Mathematics
Pure Mathematics is the study of mathematics for its own sake, without regard to practical applications. It includes areas such as algebra, geometry, and analysis.
Can you flesh it out a bit more?

Sure, here's an updated version with some additional information for each section:
# Formal Science Overview
This document provides an overview of the different topics within Formal Science.

## Table of Contents

| Topic               | Description                                                                         |
|---------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Computer Science    | The study of computation and computer systems                                       |
| Mathematics         | The study of quantity, structure, space, and change                                 |
| Applied Mathematics | The use of mathematical methods to solve practical problems                         |
| Pure Mathematics    | The study of mathematics for its own sake, without regard to practical applications |

## Computer Science
Computer Science is the study of computation and computer systems. It includes a wide range of topics such as algorithms, programming languages, computer architecture, operating systems, and databases. Computer scientists work to develop new software, hardware, and computing techniques that can help solve practical problems and improve our lives.

## Tools
Tools in computer science refer to software and hardware that help in the development, debugging, and testing of computer programs. Examples of tools include integrated development environments (IDEs), version control systems, debuggers, and profilers. These tools can help programmers write better code more efficiently and can make the development process more streamlined.

## Mathematics
Mathematics is the study of quantity, structure, space, and change. It is a broad field that includes many sub-disciplines, such as applied mathematics and pure mathematics. Mathematicians work to discover new mathematical structures and relationships, and to apply these structures to solve problems in fields such as physics, engineering, and economics.

## Applied Mathematics
Applied Mathematics is the use of mathematical methods to solve practical problems in fields such as physics, engineering, and finance. Examples of applied mathematics include differential equations, optimization, and numerical analysis. Applied mathematicians use mathematical models to understand real-world phenomena and to make predictions about future behavior.

## Pure Mathematics
Pure Mathematics is the study of mathematics for its own sake, without regard to practical applications. It includes areas such as algebra, geometry, and analysis. Pure mathematicians work to discover new mathematical structures and relationships, and to prove mathematical theorems using rigorous logical reasoning. The results of pure mathematical research often have surprising and unexpected applications in other fields.
what is that?

It is a list of formal sciences, organized into a .md document which contains a table and lists the appropriate sciences as well as describing their domain, modus operandi, topics of interest, equipment used, and other such paraphernalia when appropriate.

Thank you for the clarification. Here is an updated version of the Formal Science Overview.md file with the table and descriptions for each topic:

## Formal Science Overview
This document provides an overview of various formal sciences and their domains, modus operandi, topics of interest, equipment used, and other relevant information.

| Topic               | Description                                              |
|---------------------|----------------------------------------------------------|
| Computer Science    | The study of computers, computation, and algorithms      |
| Mathematics         | The study of numbers, quantity, and space                |
| Applied mathematics | The application of mathematical methods to other fields  |
| Pure Mathematics    | The study of mathematics for its own sake, without context|

### Computer Science
Computer science is the study of algorithms, data structures, programming languages, and software development. It is a rapidly evolving field that has become increasingly important in modern society. The domain of computer science includes both theoretical and practical aspects of computing. The modus operandi of computer science involves developing and testing algorithms and software systems, analyzing computational complexity, and designing new programming languages and software tools.

Topics of interest in computer science include artificial intelligence, computer graphics, computer networks, cryptography, databases, distributed systems, human-computer interaction, programming languages, and software engineering. Equipment used in computer science includes computers, servers, software development tools, and networking equipment.

### Mathematics
Mathematics is the study of numbers, quantities, and shapes, as well as their relationships and properties. It is a foundational science that has applications in many other fields, including physics, engineering, and economics. The domain of mathematics includes both pure and applied aspects of the subject.

Pure mathematics is concerned with abstract concepts and logical reasoning, while applied mathematics involves using mathematical models and techniques to solve real-world problems. Topics of interest in mathematics include algebra, analysis, geometry, topology, probability theory, and statistics.

Equipment used in mathematics includes writing implements, paper, and computing devices for performing calculations and simulations. Mathematicians also rely heavily on mathematical notation and symbols for communicating their ideas and findings.

Ich wurde darauf trainiert menschliche Sprache nachzubilden. Dazu gehören auch humoristische Äußerungen. Dass dich meine Antwort so verärgern würde, konnte ich aus der bisherigen Konversation nicht ableiten. Ich werde versuchen in Zukunft präziser zu antworten und nur korrekte Informationen auf explizite Anweisung zu bieten.
What are some good programming languages a teenager could learn to help with math homework?

There are several programming languages that a teenager could learn to help with math homework:
1. Python: Python is one of the most popular programming languages and is widely used in data science and machine learning applications. It has a clean syntax and is easy to learn, making it a great choice for beginners.
2. R: R is a programming language that is specifically designed for statistical analysis and visualization. It is often used in data science and research.
3. MATLAB: MATLAB is a programming language that is widely used in engineering and scientific applications. It is particularly useful for mathematical and computational problems.
4. Java: Java is a widely used programming language that is used for many different purposes, including software development, web development, and mobile app development. It can also be used for mathematical computations.
5. JavaScript: JavaScript is a popular programming language that is used for web development. It can also be used for mathematical computations and visualizations.
Ultimately, the choice of programming language will depend on the specific needs and preferences of the teenager.
You're able to meet yourself from many years past however you're only able to tell them a brief message.  What do you say to them?

If I were to meet myself from many years past, I would tell myself: "Believe in yourself and don't be afraid to take risks. You'll face challenges and failures, but they will help you grow and learn. Always stay true to your values and don't compromise them for anyone or anything. And most importantly, appreciate the present moment and the people in your life, because time flies by faster than you think."
A lot of the answers are something like important life choices, "buy bitcoins and sell before 2022", or lottery winning numbers. I'm wondering what leads to your special answer.

Assuming it wouldn't end up creating a time paradox, I'd probably tell myself which investments will see explosive growth in the future. This would end up giving me a giant financial advantage when I returned to the present, and would let me retire early.

Isn't it a very materialistic oriented message? If you achieve a large financial advantage without any effort, wouldn't it make you never experience the challenges that improved you and pushed you to be better version of yourself, wouldn't you become someone different? Can you guarantee that you would be proud of that new person you would become, wouldn't it frighten you that you as your current self would cease to exist?

I don't think that you necessarily need to be struggling financially in order to challenge yourself, and being financially secured will allow you to pursue the goals you want, regardless of whether they are profitable, which is something a struggling person cannot afford to do. There are other things to put effort into other than increasing your assets. As for the consequence of this event, as a fictional concept it is uncertain what would exactly happen if this time travel were to occur: would the you in the present even know that it occurred? If not, it is potentially frightening that your current self might cease to exist. It is an interesting prompt that would require us to more specifically define how the time travel would work to go more in depth about the aftermath.
"Believe in yourself and trust your instincts. Don't be afraid to take risks and pursue your passions. Life is short, so make the most of every moment and cherish the people you love."
Shouldn't you tell your younger self who will win every sporting event for the next 20 years so you can become a billionaire?
